summary: Colorectal cancer is a cancer that develops in the tissues of the colon or rectum, which are parts of the large intestine. It is caused by uncontrolled growth of colon cells that can invade and spread to other parts of the body. It often starts as a benign polyp and can be diagnosed through colonoscopy and medical imaging. Screening is effective for prevention and reducing deaths.
causes: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Field defects (preconditioned epithelium prone to cancer development)
risk_factors: Personal or family history of colorectal cancer
Genetic syndromes (familial adenomatous polyposis, Lynch syndrome)
Alcohol consumption (three or more drinks per day)
symptoms: Blood in the stool (bright red or very dark)
Change in bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, feeling of incomplete bowel emptying, narrower stool)
Weight loss for no known reason
diagnosis: Medical imaging (CT scan, PET scan, MRI)
Stool tests (fecal occult blood testing, fecal immunochemical testing, stool DNA screening)
Histopathology (adenocarcinoma, lymphoma, adenosquamous, squamous cell carcinoma)
treatments: Surgery (endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection, partial colectomy, proctocolectomy, cytoreductive surgery)
Chemotherapy (fluorouracil, capecitabine, oxaliplatin, irinotecan, UFT, CAPOX, FOLFOX, FOLFOXIRI, FOLFIRI)
